Beetlejuice 2 is an absolute disaster, a complete betrayal of the charm and wit of the original. The much-anticipated sequel feels like a thrown-together mess, with a storyline that’s not only incoherent but completely uninspired. It lacks the quirky charm of the first film, replacing the humor with shallow attempts at nostalgia that fall flat. The plot is a jumbled mishmash of random ideas, none of which are executed well. Instead of building on the unique, surreal tone of the original Beetlejuice, this sequel goes for awkward, forced moments that barely make sense. The pacing is all over the place, leaving you wondering if they even had a clear vision from the start. What should’ve been an exciting continuation of a beloved universe is instead a tedious, forgettable slog. The new characters are unbearable. They’re nothing more than shallow caricatures, each one less interesting than the last. Lydia’s daughter, played by Jenna Ortega, is an attempt to inject some new life into the series, but her character lacks any depth or real connection to the world we once loved. The charm of the original cast is sorely missed, and it’s painfully obvious that they couldn’t quite find a replacement. Even Winona Ryder, who once embodied Lydia with such effortless cool, seems lost in this mess, as if she’s barely holding it together. The visual effects, while technically decent, feel overdone and uninspired, and the film’s attempt to recapture the macabre atmosphere of the first movie only results in a hollow, empty imitation. Ultimately, Beetlejuice 2 is a missed opportunity. It tries so hard to recapture the magic of the original, but it doesn’t succeed in any meaningful way. What we’re left with is a forgettable, frustratingly disappointing sequel that is best left avoided. It’s hard to believe this is the same franchise that once captivated audiences with its creativity and wit.

Beetlejuice Beetlejuice was really, really fun! Ryder, O’Hara, and Keaton were astonishingly good, like they hadn’t missed a single step since the prior film (which was released way back in ‘88). The return to practical and stop-motion effects enhanced the overall tone and vibe, and (newer cast entry) Willem Dafoe chewed scenery like the set was a mouthful of watermelon-flavored Hubba-Bubba. The downsides were the plot lines seemed a bit meandering, leaving the picture feeling like Burton had 3-4 ideas, and rather than focus on getting 1-2 narratives really solidified, he just threw everything in there, leaving some characters and plot points unresolved and/or under utilized (no spoilers, but I wanted-and the film could’ve used- about 850% more Monica Bellucci). That and well…we have to address the 61” tall elephant in the room. Jenna Ortega, as much as I dig her in interviews, isn’t a strong actor. Ortega’s performances over the past few years have ranged between mildly adequate to somewhat passable at best. In Beetlejuice Beetlejuice however, she was soundly outclassed in every second she was onscreen. Anytime she shared scenes with her other castmates, her lack of chops were awkwardly apparent. Not enough to ruin the scene- or the picture- but distractingly mediocre nonetheless. Overall though, this is one of the stronger legacy sequels out there. I was skeptical about a studio letting Burton revisit his 30 year old property, but was pleasantly surprised at how much I dug it. And if you liked the ‘88 Beetlejuice film (and grossly underrated cartoon series), you’ll dig it too…

I eagerly anticipated the sequel to the movie Beetlejuice. It is one of my favorite movies. I loved the atmosphere the film creates, and the quirky characters. Every character makes sense, in their own weird way. The sequel left me wanting more. The character of Beetlejuice, for one thing, appears far too often in the sequel. He is a very important, but side, character in the original. He is a main character in this film, and that does not really work. His ex-is fun for about a minute, and the coworkers he has in sales are just silly. It makes no sense he’s got so many shrunken head dudes… The Maitlands are the heart of the film, with the Deetz family. They are just gone, and the Deetz family is, disappointing. Lydia is weak. I liked Delia’s character in this, but Lydia has grown soft and uninteresting in this movie. Her daughter is trying to carry the torch on the film, and only manages to do so some of the time. Overall the film was disappointing. I will watch the original again; I will not be re-watching this sequel.

I don't think that he can take it 'Cause it took so long to bake it And he'll never have that recipe again A fun, whacky film. It has the style and look of a Tim Burton movie, but not the feeling. None of the characters feel particularly relatable, and there are a lot of them; too many, in fact, with only a few receiving any meaningful development. This leads to multiple plotlines that ultimately go nowhere. Monica Bellucci’s character, while visually stunning, serves more as a plot device to give Beetlejuice a sense of urgency rather than as a fully realized character. The structure is also problematic; we get only brief glimpses of what normal life looks like for our protagonists before the inciting incidents and act break. By the midpoint, the film becomes predictable, leading to an ending that fails to tie everything together in a satisfying way, relying instead on a deus ex machina resolution similar to the original film. Scene transitions often feel awkward, frequently involving characters who have no real relevance to the plot. On the positive side, the production design and cinematography are effectively artsy and expressionistic. The visual effects, while some might find them “goofy-looking,” are in line with the film’s world-building and tone, paying homage to the practical effects used in the first installment. The acting is solid, though not outstanding, but Michael Keaton’s effortless return to the role after more than 30 years is definitely a highlight. Ultimately, the film disappoints when compared to its predecessor. It would have benefited from being told strictly from the mother and daughter’s POV, cutting down the excess plotlines and significantly reducing the role of other characters—including Beetlejuice himself. Despite my criticisms, it’s still an entertaining watch, worth checking out for fans of Tim Burton and the original Beetlejuice—but beware.

Beetlejuice Beetlejuice is a shockingly good movie that delivers effects, story, comedy, and overall fun. What seemed to be just another nostalgia grab for Gen Xers and elder Millennials was instead a cascading romp through the diverse embodiments of the afterlife and Connecticut. There is some gnarly stuff here that I did not recall from the original (at least not this much), which really leans into the “horror” half of the horror-comedy subgenre. The Deetzs are back (at least 3 ½ of them) (Winona Ryder, Catherine O’Hara, Jenna Ortega, Mark Heenehan) and complement each other perfectly — O’Hara is so good in this role that you miss her when the plot follows one of its many other lines. There are a number of threads in this story that, instead of a burden, are intriguing and necessary, but three of which could have used more development — Delores LaFevre (Monica Bellucci), a soul-sucking witch and Beetleguese’s (Michael Keaton) ex-wife, Richard (Santiago Cabrera), Lydia’s (Ryder) late-husband and motivation for Astrid’s (Ortega) to the “other side,” and Jeremy (Arthur Conti), Astrid’s love-interest and best twist of the movie that is resolved way too quickly. This movie could’ve used another 20–30 minutes easy. I also loved Willem Dafoe as an actor who did his own stunts (not always effectively) and has turned to solving crime in the Afterlife. Even in shitty movies, Dafoe is the man. The look of the movie is iconic and feels like a comeback for Tim Burton. There’s just something about that opening music from Danny Elfman that makes me smile.

Too dark, depressing and scary to be enjoyable. I kept thinking, "Is this hell?" Because it sure didn't look like heaven. Lots of evil characters in this one. The marriage license went up in flames because? Delia Dietz didn't check the asps before putting them on her neck and then accepts her fate like that? There is a portal for dead and living? Astrid could find exactly the page she needed for the sandworms in five seconds? There is no one to root for in this movie. Lydia's character is feckless and spineless. She agrees to marry her smarmy manager, lets her daughter speak badly to her, then agrees to marry Beetlejuice to prove her love to her daughter. Astrid is a total jerk until the end. Charles Dietz's dead body is horrendous. This movie is clever. But enjoyable? No.

Filme: Beetlejuice Assistido: 19-01-25 Elenco: @timburton @michaelkeatondouglas @winonaryderofficialn @jennaortega @monicabellucciofficiel @justintheroux @arthurstanleyconti @dannydevito9 @willemdafoesact @burngorman1 @catherineoharas Modelo: #trash #comedia #fantasia Duração: 1h 44m Ano: 2024 Minha opinião: Eu não assisti o 1º filme de 1988 que também tinha um elenco de 1ª Geena Davis, Alec Baldwin, Jeffrey Jones e 36 anos depois estão de volta Michael Keaton, Winona Ryder e Catherine O’Hara. Aqui temos também o diretor Tim Burton de volta. Com boas atuações de todos os atores. De terror não tem nada no filme. Tem até coreografia do Michael Jackson de Triller, pena que não usaram sua música. Temos Danny por alguns minutos e já morre, temos Dafoe fazendo um papel que se não existisse não mudaria em nada. Temos Monica aqui como sendo a ex-esposa de Beetle que agora revive e esta com cede de vingança por Beetle a fazer picadinho dela, e agora ela pode matar um fantasma, pois ela sulga sua essência. E a filha de Lydia acaba indo para o mundo fantasma enganado por um fantasma que quer sua vida em troca do dela. E para isso Lydia assina um contrato com Beetle para ir ao mundo dos fantasmas e salva-la e ai ta toda trama. O filme tenta tirar risada, mas não consegue. E mais para assistir o estilo trash e fantasia do filme. Roteiro e enredo não tem como comparar com o 1º porque não assisti. Um filme que teve um alto orçamento de 100 milhões de dólares e arrecadou 450 milhões de dólares. Vale apena assistir? Sim, mas sabendo que é bem trash o filme. Nota: 7

I would give this film 3.5 stars because I enjoyed the originality of the plot, it did not merely seem like an extended first movie while also building on and advancing the characters introduced by the first movie. I think that adding in Jenna Ortega was a good choice and she added to the series nicely with an interesting character that helped build up a new plot and fill in gaps of Lydia's life until this point. However the film did feel a little all over the place at times with jumps to different antagonists which made it feel a bit crowded and flow more choppy. Overall I was happy to see the progression in Delia, Lydia, and Beetlejuice's characters and appreciated the film, it is definitely something I would recommend watching once for the experience and comedy but not something I would reach for to watch a second time.

BEETLEJUICE 2 is a suitably zany sequel, which wisely keeps with the style and spirit of the classic original by utilizing plenty of practical effects and wacky weirdness. We learn a little more about Beetlejuice's mysterious origins, and the structure of this hilariously bureaucratic underworld, but like the original, this film resolutely commits to story and antics over exposition. It's ghoulish without being overtly scary, and maintains a special brand of dark comedy all its own.

Being an absolute, lifetime, fan girl for Beetlejuice since the original, I have been waiting YEARS for this second movie. With that said, certain expectations, hopes, ideas, thoughts (the list goes on) have definitely formed (and re-formed) over the years in anticipation. So, going into this I tried my hardest not to let my hopes get too high, spiral too far out of hand, or allow myself to succumb to, too many preconceived notions or expectations upon movie number 2s emergence. Thus, when the eventual disappointment came (as I felt it inevitability would, especially with the endless ongoings and downfalls of late with/in/among Hollywood and the like), this disheartened fan would be well prepared for the walk of shame. The exiting of the theater in this presumed state of depression, would be at a point still capable of returning my empty shell of a being which remained to my home instead of ending it all there on the spot. Such preparation, hopefully, in part, may save some poor, unsuspecting soul the task of a messy clean up. However, upon viewing Beetlejuice Beetlejuice in its entirety, I must now repent of my wicked ways by admitting that while it isnt the first movie (understandably so), if one can pick up on the subtleties peppered throughout, understanding the history, sinister soul and dark brilliant mind of Tim Burton along with a running knowledge of his work and love of all things horror, this is an EXCELLENT movie which provides a deep glimpse into his life and art. Without some understanding of Mr Burton himself, however, one might find it cheesy and not be able to understand much of the cut-aways or references made in some of the backstory illustrated throughout. With that said, I would definitely recommend several viewings of this movie so as not to miss any of the aforementioned aspects.

The plot is signposted a little too easily and it perhaps relies a little too hard on Keaton to carry it. Are these things awful? Absolutely not. Could it have been better? Probably. Is it a decent addition to the Burton-verse? For sure.

Beetlejuice (Michael Keaton) kehrt nach 36 Jahren zurück. Dieser ist immer noch in Lydia Deetz (Winona Ryder) verliebt und will sie heiraten, um aus der Totenwelt zu entkommen. Lydia Deetzs Vater ist gestorben und sie kehrt in die alte Stadt zurück, wo sie ihre Tochter Astrid (Jenna Ortega) wieder trifft. Durch verschiedenste Geschichten und Ereignissen, braucht Lydia Hilfe von Beetlejuice, doch kann sie ihm trauen. Die Fortsetzung der Horrorkomödie Beetlejuice, sorgt für viel Unterhaltung. Tim Burton führt wieder Regie und er kehrt hier zu seinen alten Wurzeln zurück. Die neueren Filme mögen, viele nicht, ich persönlich, konnte mit Alice im Wunderland und Big Eyes etwas anfangen. Die Schauspieler im Film haben den Spaß Ihres Lebens. Michael Keaton spielt wieder sensationell gut und unterhaltend. Die neuen Charaktere funktionieren, ebenfalls, besonders Willem Dafoe als Cop (ehemaliger Schauspieler) hat richtig viel Spaß. Seine Figur wird leider, etwas verschwendet und hätte mehr Screentime verdient. Viele Kritiker haben dem Film vorgeworfen, dass er zu viel erzählt und das Ende sich gerusht anfühlt. Kann ich zwar nachvollziehen, aber für mich hat das alles Sinn, ergeben und das Finale wurde gut aufgebaut. Den ersten Teil habe ich nur einmal gesehen mit Werbung. Laut meinen Erinnerungen, finde ich diesen hier, aber unterhaltsamer und besser. Ob dies noch der Fall ist, werde ich noch überprüfen. Die Musik im Film ist wieder passend, außer während der Beerdigung, dort wurde der Banana Song abgespielt, das war nicht nötig. Am Ende kann man sagen, das Beetlejuice Beetlejuice eine super Fortsetzung ist und ich würde mich über einen 3 Teil sehr freuen.

Watching BEETLEJUICE BEETLEJUCIE, the latest in a series of decades-in-the-making sequels to beloved 80’s movies, confirmed an unconscious suspicion I must have carried since the exhilarating ride that was last year’s “TOP GUN: Maverick”: A follow-up to a defining movie from one’s youth is the ideal vehicle for TIME TRAVEL. Consider the evidence: It’s EFFICIENT (access emotional memory archives, check!), SAFE (absent awkward hairdo photos, check plus!), and CONVENIENT (guaranteed drop-off at point of pick-up, ding ding ding!). 🕕 It sure helps the journey when said sequel is as FUN & SPIRITED (pun intended) as what must be Tim Burton’s most enjoyable LIVE ACTION film in 30 years… welcome to 2x1 puns Happy Hour! 🥸 🍸 I can’t decide if the reason for what could have been a WRECK deserves so much PRAISE is whether Burton has finally decided he has nothing to prove, OR the cast wells so well this feels like a Christopher Guest improv farce. The ORIGINAL CAST reprise their roles splendidly, Winona Ryder the slight exception. Her Lydia seems stuck in a “Stranger” version of Joyce Bear’s worry wart . The NEW CAST fall into a spectrum from outstanding (Jenna Ortega proving she’s twice the actress darling Winona ever was) to mediocre (sweet Monica Bellucci deserved that medieval slap from Beetlegeuse!). 👋🏼 Or maybe I LOVED BEETLEJUICE 2 simply because the film is a great sum of its parts: Sexagenarian weirdo genius creator + solid crazy cast + superb lifelong craft collaborators in couture, music, set design & special effects + silly script mixing the most RECYCLABLE slapstick concepts (After-life surreal desert, Kill-me-now-oh-wait-you-can’t-cause-I’m already DEAD waiting room) with FRESH slapstick concepts inspired by the original (“SOUL” TRAIN? LMFAO) = Let’s Get Whimsical! Please pass the Olivia Newton-John leotards.. I’m in the mood for silly 🤸‍♀️🤸‍♀️🤸‍♀️ It’s no spoiler calling for a moratorium on bathroom breaks lest you miss out on moments, such as the cameo of Richard Marx’s voice via a most unexpected “Right Here Waiting” serenade. 🪕 Or the catharsis in the hysterical “Take THAT you soul-sucking Influencers!” scene. Or EVERY minute of “Never Schittier” scene-stealer Catherine “The GREAT” O’Hara - Huzzah!! The hands down ABSOLUTE BEST MOMENT? That marionette show climactic dance sequence to “MacArthur Park”. SO good it’s UP THERE with the original “Day-O” dinner table sextet.. With this instant classic moment, MONSIEUR BURTON has perfected the art of taking a CHEESY song and cooking up a RACLETTE symphony. 🧀 🫕 In a movie that had me giggling like my 13-year old self again, that moment simply takes the cake. Pun Pun Pun. ‘Nuff Said. Ps #RIPBOB Kevin Redman Cris Herrera Jorge Herrera please watch, roll on the floor, and call me in the morning! 📞🙏🏽

This was a competent and clever sequel that lives up to it's predecessor in almost every way. It helps having the majority of the original cast, as well as some welcomed new faces. It's also nice having Tim Burton back in the director's seat. He was able to keep the feel from the original and translate it just enough to keep the style without it feeling like a stale rehash. Nice job, Tim! My only negative for the film is it takes quite a while before we get to all the Beetlejuice stuff. Granted, there is a lot of story to cover between the original and now, but some of it could have been condensed into shorter segments. Overall, it's a true to the original sequel with all the zany and quirky natured things the original has. Even if it takes a bit to get started, once it does, you'll be hooked. If you were not a fan of the original, this one will not change your mind. However, if you were a fan and you crave more story, you can't go wrong with this albeit unnecessary, but welcomed, sequel.

I can’t lie: as a Tim Burton and Beetleguese enjoyer, I got a kick out of it. It wasn’t bad… but it wasn’t really good either. SPOILERS AHEAD. Positive: - easter eggs from the original - used real materials like clay and wood to make the creatures (I was scared they would digitize everything) - funny puns - fast paced Negative: - they *obliterated* Lydia’s character, she is not even the same person, and this new Lydia is highly unlikeable. Also, why does she have the same hairstyle and outfit as she did when she was a teenager? What is this, a cartoon? - celebrity cast with poor acting - cheesy - (this is my biggest complaint) the ghost couple living in the house from the first movie are now gone, with one line of dialogue about a vague “loophole” to explain their absence… 🤦 Why the good ratings? Simple. People like Tim Burton, and they like Beetleguese. Let’s face it, y’all wouldn’t tolerate this bs otherwise. I just wish that people had skipped badgering Wes Anderson over Asteroid City, and saved their energy to dunk Burton instead.

Forced nostalgia, slipping performances, many re-hashed bits make this decades-in-the-offing sequel just not worth it. In the original, Beetlejuice's range of "powers" in various situations were novel and fun because the situations were unique and the "solutions" were very amusing responses to stimuli... In this sequel, it's clear that the writers never bothered to consider extending his "powers" to fit the new scenarios. His powers mostly consist of impersonations, popping up behind people, singing oldies, and making others lip sync to oldies. They had an imaginary world of the afterlife to play with and gave us a handful of regurgitated jokes (shrinking people down into the town model, scary face from behind, zipping Lydia's mouth shut, etc) and 25+ minutes of sing-alongs including a Choral "Day-O", which we have to assume became Charles Deetz's favorite song after the trauma inflicted on the family at that dinner 30 years ago? Strange. One of the "main" plotlines of Astrid's abduction lacks any drama or feeling... The revelation that she can also see the dead like her mother just sails by... The rescue and dispatching of her abductor is so brief it mutes any possible suspense of the peril she was in. Again, choices were made to spend a HUGE amount of time on an old country sing-along wedding scene rather than service the underlying story. Just baffling decisions on so many fronts. The other "main" plot line of Beetlejuice's scorned former love is again very rushed and sloppy. We get a 5-minute setup in French, providing some insight into his origin as a graverobber, his death at the hands of a cultist, but shockingly nothing on how he actually became this immensely powerful renegade ghoul. More questionable decisions. The courtship of Lydia, birth of Astrid, and death of Astrid's father are handled onscreen with a few lines of dialogue, but for some reason they needed to turn Jeffery Jones' Charles Deetz into a long drawn out claymation segment to justify a deus-ex machina in the afterlife that really did nothing at all. Was this just to insult the man for his legal issues? So baffling and a massive budget and time suck for very little payoff and story advancement. Very questionable decision making. I clearly have a lot of issues with the Direction, writing, and storytelling in this sequel-that-probably-shouldn't-have-been-made. There weren't enough fresh and/or fun elements to balance that bad out to make it worthwhile.

I’ve been reading some reviews, and it seems like many people rated the movie highly because they felt it wasn’t bad compared to other sequels. Sure, sequels are tough—recapturing the charm of the original is no small feat. But Beetlejuice 2 doesn’t deserve a score similar to the first because, frankly, it’s just not as good. The foundation is there—a solid premise and some intriguing conflict, especially between Lydia, her mother, and her daughter. But the execution fell flat. The payoffs didn’t feel earned, and the story seemed to coast more on its quirky visuals than meaningful development. I appreciated Tim Burton’s restraint in limiting Beetlejuice’s screen time to avoid overexposure—a smart choice—but that restraint was undercut by the overemphasis on Burton’s other supernatural aesthetics. At times, it felt like the film was trying too hard to dazzle with its weirdness, leaving the characters and plotlines underdeveloped. The first Beetlejuice worked because it centered on its characters, with the weirdness enhancing the story rather than overpowering it. In this sequel, the balance tipped too far, and the promising elements—particularly the family dynamics—never fully took shape. It had its moments, but overall? Meh. I just couldn’t bring myself to care about any of the characters.

Thank you, Tim Burton, for another enchanting masterpiece! I've really missed seeing the brilliance of this director. Beetlejuice 2 brings back the dark and quirky universe that won over so many fans, this time with a fresh touch and a stellar cast. The sequel is just as entertaining as the original, further enriching the narrative. The visual effects are excellent and perfectly preserve the unique atmosphere that's Tim Burton's trademark. Winona Ryder still looks stunning and, as Lydia Deetz, continues to shine and steal the spotlight. Jenna Ortega, playing her daughter, also delivers an outstanding performance. She's an actress who feels like she stepped straight out of a Tim Burton film, embodying his style flawlessly. And, of course, Michael Keaton, reprising his role as Beetlejuice, is absolutely phenomenal, breathing life back into the iconic character. That said, the story does fall short in some areas, with certain acts moving too quickly, which hurts the development of some situations and makes it harder for the audience to connect with certain characters. Even so, the film's humor and charm more than make up for these flaws, making it a lighthearted and thoroughly enjoyable experience. Overall, Beetlejuice 2 is a sequel worthy of the original, with a solid cast, impressive effects, and all the magic only Tim Burton can create. It's a beautiful tribute to the legacy of the first film and a real treat for fans.

I had no expectations going into this one. I wasn't against the idea of a sequel to the original, but Beetlejuice is one of my favorite movies of any decade and, honestly, I'd always assumed it was a brilliantly original one-and-done, a notion I was fine with. But here we are decades later and a sequel we have been given. To my surprise and great delight, I really enjoyed Beetlejuice Beetlejuice. It's a funny , highly entertaining sequel that is cluttered with too many story threads, but is elevated by a knockout performance from Michael Keaton as the ghost with the most and the best work Tim Burton has delivered behind the camera in years. The entire cast is terrific - Winona Ryder does great work as an older Lydia and Jenna Ortega is perfect as her daughter.. But special praise has to be given to Catherine O'Hara, who returns as Delia Deitz. O Hara is naturally funny anyway, but she's absolutely this movie's secret weapon .. Delia is still Delia, but this time the daffy artist from the original has gained some wisdom over the years and O'Hara does a tremendous job of not only making her funny again, but giving the audience a reason to actually care about her. The visuals are a winning mix of limited CGI work and almost wall to wall practical effects, so this feels like the same world. One sidebar I have to mention: All of the plot threads are eventually pulled together in a brilliant, genuinely funny sequence set to Richard Harris' version of MacArthur Park that may be the single best thing Tim Burton has ever done. This sequence is easily a high water mark in the career of both Burton and Keaton (who gloriously takes it up to eleven in this scene) and it's the coup de grace that elevates this sequel to being almost on the same level as the original. Almost. As I mentioned, there are too many plot threads and, honestly, some rewriting could have had this movie end in the same place while losing the storylines involving Justin Theroux and Willem Dafoe. They're both good in their roles, but they feel unnecessary to this movie. But those are minor quibbles. Beetlejuice Beetlejuice was smarter, funnier and more respectful to the original than I could have hoped. It's a terrific sequel and I highly recommend it. **** out of *****..

Rather than elevating the material, Keaton seems to coast through scenes, relying on the character's established quirks instead of pushing for something fresh or memorable. Combined with a messy, unfocused script and uninspired humor, the film comes across as lazy overall, leaning too heavily on nostalgia without adding anything meaningful to the story or characters. It’s a missed opportunity to properly revisit such an iconic role and world.

Nostalgic, But Lacking the Original’s Magic As a lifelong fan of Tim Burton’s 1988 classic Beetlejuice, I was thrilled to see the return of the “ghost with the most.” However, while Beetlejuice 2 boasts a talented cast and Burton’s signature visual style, it ultimately feels more like a rehashed homage to the original than a worthy sequel. Michael Keaton is once again fantastic as the mischievous Beetlejuice, effortlessly slipping back into the role with his trademark chaos and charm. Winona Ryder also shines in her return as Lydia Deetz, now older but still deeply connected to the macabre. The newer additions to the cast, including Jenna Ortega, bring energy and charisma, but even their performances can’t overcome the film's overly familiar plot. Rather than building on the creativity and innovation of the original, Beetlejuice 2 plays it safe. It recycles many of the same jokes, scenarios, and themes without adding much that feels new or exciting. For viewers unfamiliar with the first movie, this might not be an issue—it’s quirky and fun enough to entertain. However, for fans of the 1988 classic, it’s hard not to feel disappointed by the lack of originality. What made Beetlejuice a cultural phenomenon was its boldness, unpredictability, and unique charm. While the sequel has moments of humor and nostalgia, it fails to capture the same spark that made the original timeless. In the end, Beetlejuice 2 is a decent watch for casual audiences but a missed opportunity for fans hoping for a fresh and inventive continuation of the story.

Keaton’s return as Beetlejuice is undeniably energetic, with his manic energy elevating the film's more chaotic moments. His chemistry with Ryder's Lydia, now a grown goth queen, remains an endearing feature of the film. However, some of the new characters, like Monica Bellucci’s Delores, lack depth despite their visually striking introductions The film thrives when it embraces its dark, quirky charm, with Burton incorporating old-fashioned effects and puppetry that stand out against the modern CGI-driven spectacle. Though some of the film’s gory sequences (including a dismembered ghost) might border on absurdity, they contribute to the film’s delightfully twisted aesthetic. However, the script at times gets tangled in its new additions, with certain plot threads underdeveloped. Overall, Beetlejuice Beetlejuice is a fun, if messy, sequel that captures some of the original’s charm while adding a contemporary, albeit complicated, twist to the afterlife mischief. If you're a fan of Burton's distinctive style and Keaton's chaotic performance, it’s definitely worth the watch.

Beetlejuice Beetlejuice is among the better half of legacy sequels. It's entertaining, just like the original, though admittedly less compelling. The film is packed with too much stuff, and that’s its main problem. There are too many storylines and characters, and some plot points either seem forgotten or quickly brushed aside. For the most part, the film succeeds in delivering a fun and engaging experience. It genuinely captures the essence of a Beetlejuice sequel, with Michael Keaton at his best. In fact, the entire main cast is excellent, especially the returning actors from the original. Jenna Ortega is also pretty great as a new addition to the cast. However, some characters feel unnecessary — for instance, Beetlejuice's ex-wife, who didn't end up having much of a role and is at times forgotten. Also Willem Dafoe’s brilliant talent deserves more screen time! Still, the movie is fun. While it doesn’t break new ground, the film is bigger and flashier than its predecessor, and it tries a lot, succeeding in certain aspects. Overall, it works well and is visually stunning and atmospheric, even if the story falters at times. Ultimately, Burton's sequel is a film worth watching and a solid addition to the Beetlejuice legacy.

This movie was exactly what I expected! It was funny and I enjoyed seeing both the old and new characters! I wasn't super impressed with Rory or Delores' characters, that part was kind of meh. I also wish Jeremy wasn't a bad guy. However, Astrid and Lydia were great together! it was such a fun movie and it made me laugh and feel nostalgic.
I liked how it paid homage to the first one, but it needed its own spin.

Not nearly in the same brilliance as the original Beetlejuice, this is too slick (the digital filming removes a lot of the uniqueness) and scatterbrained to work fully. Monica Bellucci's character is almost entirely superfluous although makes for a great sight gag. Her story just seems tacked on for no reason. Unlike the original, which had a main villain (Beetlejuice) to focus on, this one seems to try and turn Beetlejuice into a tortured hero. The cast is still fantastic (although Justin Theroux's character is almost entirely pointless), the music is great, the use of visual effects is great. But overall, it doesn't leave the same lasting impact that the original did. It feels like the screenplay was trying to do too much to give fan service.
Fun entertainment. Loved all the all star actors.

I love the original but the sequel didn't have the same charm. Michael Keaton is still great as BJ. The plot was dumb with lazy writing. Beetlejuice deserved a better story than this.
Nostalgic & funny. Super surprised

As excited I was for this movie, I feel it does not wholly capture the originals charm. This however doesn't mean it was a "bad" movie. I simply have a few major problems with characters such as Beetlejuices Ex who was seemingly set up to be a major antagonist towards beetleJuice, but I was ultimately disappointed for her to simply end by being killed by a sand worm. A more major problem I had was with the B plot of Astrid and Jeremy. Once again, there was potential for a better antagonist. But the character of Jeremy felt very rushed and simply fell flat just like BeetleJuices Ex wife. Besides these 2 flaws, this movie was very enjoyable and certainly has that Tim Burton charm we all know and love. I simply hope it doesn't take another 30 years for a sequel.
